    Identification of a Novel TAR RNA-Binding Protein 2 Modulator with Potential Therapeutic Activity against Hepatocellular Carcinoma

    SUBJECTS:
    • Cells,
    • Cancer,
    • Peptides and proteins,
    • Genetics,
    • Protein dynamics
    Get e-Alerts

    Abstract

    Imbalance miRNAs contribute to tumor formation; therefore, the development of small-molecule compounds that regulate miRNA biogenesis is an important strategy in oncotherapy. Here, (−)-Gomisin M1 (GM) was found to modulate miRNA biogenesis to inhibit the proliferation, migration, and invasion of hepatocellular carcinoma (HCC) cells. GM modulated expression profiles of miRNA and protein in HCC cells and suppressed tumor growth in a mouse model. Mechanistically, GM affected miRNA maturation by targeting TAR RNA-binding protein 2 (TRBP), with an efficacy higher than that of enoxacin, and promoted the binding of TRBP with Dicer. Structural simplification and a preliminary structure–activity relationship study via the synthesis of 20 GM derivatives showed that compound 9 exhibited more potent inhibitory activity in HCC cell proliferation and affinity for TRBP than did GM. These results suggest that TRBP may be a novel potential therapeutic target in HCC and compound 9 may be a potential drug candidate for the treatment of HCC.

    Introduction

    ARTICLE SECTIONS
    Jump To
    HCC is the fourth most common cause of cancer-related death and ranks sixth in terms of incidence among all cancers in the world.(1) Patients with liver disease are vulnerable to the development of HCC, mostly as a result of hepatitis B or C virus infection or bibulosity. Under these conditions, DNA alterations occur frequently, including mutations and chromosomal aberrations in the TERT promoter, TP53, CTNNB1, and AXIN1.(1) However, systemic small-molecule drugs inhibit receptor tyrosine kinases and do not target these mutated genes or proteins directly. Multi-kinase inhibitors have been approved for the treatment of HCC, including the first-line therapies sorafenib and lenvatinib. However, the one-year median survival time remains short.(2,3) Therapies currently in development include angiogenesis inhibitors and immune checkpoint inhibitors, which show similar median survival times compared with that of sorafenib.(4) Therefore, it is imperative to explore more innovative drugs and effective targets for HCC therapy. MicroRNAs (miRNAs) are involved in a variety of physiological processes and are associated with multifarious diseases through coordination of gene expression at the post-transcriptional level. Accumulating evidence suggests that the expression profiles of microRNAs differ significantly between patients with HCC and healthy individuals, and this aberrant expression promotes the proliferation, invasion, and metastasis of HCC.(5) Furthermore, clinical studies have indicated that different miRNAs could be used as prognostic biomarkers for the development of liver cancer or for predicting treatment outcomes.(6) Thus, treatment strategies for HCC that modulate intracellular miRNA levels are of interest. Indeed, miRNAs as novel targets for nucleotide-based drugs have great appeal in the development of HCC therapies.(7) However, exogenous RNAs can induce off-target effects, are difficult to deliver, induce immunogenicity, and are associated with serious safety issues in clinical settings.(8,9) In addition, the functions of various miRNAs remain unclear because changes in a single miRNA, unlike a protein-coding gene, rarely lead to a specific phenotype.(10) In fact, some small molecules have been reported to regulate cancer growth and metastasis in multifarious cancers by inhibiting the expression of miR-21 or miR-122 and others. Therefore, regulating global miRNA homeostasis by chemical small molecules may represent a potential novel therapeutic strategy in oncotherapy.(11)
    TRBP, a key component of the miRNA-induced silencing complex (RISC), affects miRNA biogenesis by ensuring the efficient and accurate Dicer processing of precursor microRNA in RNA-crowded environments(12) or by modulating RISC assembly and Ago2-induced miRNA stability.(13,14) In addition, miRNA expression can be influenced by extracellular regulated protein kinases (ERK) or S6 kinase 2 (S6K2) kinase-mediated TRBP phosphorylation.(15,16) Furthermore, TRBP is involved in the development and progression of various cancers.(17) The level of expression of TRBP is reduced in cancer stem cells of Ewing sarcoma family tumors (ESFTs), resulting in the mRNA profile becoming disordered.(17) However, TRBP can function as a tumor suppressor or promoter, with different expression levels reported in diverse cancers. For example, TRBP was found to be upregulated in prostate cancer and adrenocortical carcinoma and downregulated in colorectal cancer, ESFT, and upper urinary tract urothelial carcinoma.(18) Therefore, the function of TRBP in cancer, particularly in HCC, remains unclear. Further research is needed to confirm whether the role of TRBP in tumorigenesis is cell context-dependent and whether TRBP function is dependent on different regulatory patterns.
    Enoxacin, a fluoroquinolone antibacterial drug, is the only known TRBP agonist that enhances miRNA biogenesis and inhibits cancer growth.(19) However, enoxacin was reported to suppress the proliferation of colon cancer cells with low potency (IC50 > 100 μM) and low affinity for TRBP (affinity constant; KD ∼ 12.56 μM).(11) Therefore, it is necessary to develop new small molecules targeting TRBP to better understand the homeostasis of miRNA biosynthesis in HCC. GM, a natural dibenzocyclooctadiene lignan isolated from Schisandra chinensis,(20) has been shown to exhibit anti-inflammatory,(21) antioxidant,(22) advanced glycation end-product inhibitor,(23) and anti-human immunodeficiency virus (HIV)(24) activity. However, its role in the suppression of HCC tumorigenesis remains unclear. GM analogues such as Gomisin A and Gomisin N have been found to exhibit inhibitory effects on proliferation and carcinogenesis of HCC,(25−28) but the effects of these gomisins on miRNAs expression and their molecular targets remain unclear. Here, we found that GM modulates TRBP-mediated miRNA biogenesis and exhibits potent anti-hepatoma effects by reconstituting tumor-related proteins and signaling pathways in vitro and in vivo. Analysis of the structure–activity relationship identified GM analogues that target TRBP with increased specificity versus that of enoxacin. This study supports the role of TRBP as a potential therapeutic target as well as further development of GM or its analogues as novel drug candidates for the modulation of miRNA biogenesis in HCC.

    Results

    ARTICLE SECTIONS
    Jump To

    GM Modulates miRNA Biogenesis to Suppress HCC Proliferation and Metastasis In Vitro

    We established a screening assay based on HeLa-miR-21-luciferase cells, in which the luciferase reporter was used to evaluate variation in endogenous miR-21 (Figure 1A). A compound library consisting of 1431 diverse natural and synthetic compounds(29) was screened (Figure S1A), and GM was found to significantly decrease the intensity of the luciferase signal with better efficacy than enoxacin (Figure S1B). The chemical structure of GM is shown in Figure 1B. GM increased the level of miR-21 biogenesis with a median effective concentration (IC50) of 17.15 μM (Figure 1C). Compared with that of GM, the IC50 of enoxacin was 25.77 μM (Figure 1D). To determine the specificity of GM for miRNA biogenesis, miRNA production in SK-Hep-1 cells was evaluated following treatment with GM or enoxacin. The level of expression of tumor suppressors, including miR-122-5p,(30) miR-26a-5p,(31) and miR-214-5p,(32) was increased, along with the level of expression of oncomir miR-21-5p(33) and miR-106b-5p(34) (Figure 1E). Additionally, the levels of oncomiRs miR-224-5p(35) and miR-452-5p(29) decreased, along with the levels of tumor suppressor miR-30a-5p(36) (Figure 1E). There was no significant effect on the production of miR-222-5p, miR-10a-5p, miR-135a-5p, and miR-22-5p (Figure 1E). However, in contrast to GM, enoxacin increased the levels of miR-106b-5p, miR-21-5p, miR-26a-5p, and miR-22-5p and decreased those of miR135a-5p and miR-30a-5p (Figure 1F). To verify whether changes in mature miRNAs were due to the influence of upstream miRNA biogenesis, the level of expression of corresponding primary miRNAs (pri-miRNAs) and precursor miRNAs (pre-miRNAs) was measured. Expression of these pri-miRNAs and pre-miRNAs remained largely unchanged (Figure S2A,B), suggesting that GM modulated the expression of a subset of miRNAs. GM was then examined for its antineoplastic activity against liver cancer cells (SK-Hep-1, MHCC97, HepG2, and Huh7), breast cancer cells (MDA-MB-231), colorectal cancer cells (HCT116), cervical cancer cells (HeLa), and immortalized hepatic normal cells (QSG-7701). GM dose-dependently inhibited the proliferation of SK-Hep-1 cells with a half-maximal inhibitory concentration (IC50) of 20.56 μM (Figure S3A) compared with enoxacin, which had an IC50 of 25.03 μM (Figure S3B). GM significantly suppressed the proliferation of MHCC97, HepG2, Huh7, and HeLa cells but not MDA-MB-231 and HCT116 cells at 25 μM (Figure S3C). Consistent with this, the IC50 values of GM on these cell lines were calculated as 24.75 μM (MHCC97), 27.26 μM (HepG2), 32.23 μM (Huh7), 32.83 μM (HeLa), 56.61 μM (MDA-MB-231), 55.38 μM (HCT116), and 68.86 μM (QSG-7701) (Figure S3D–J). GM inhibited colony formation in SK-Hep-1 cells (Figure 1G). Furthermore, GM significantly inhibited the clonogenic capacity of the other six cancer cell lines compared with the cells treated with DMSO (dimethyl sulfoxide) and more potently than enoxacin, especially in SK-Hep-1 and MHCC97 cells (Figure 1G and Figure S4A). GM induced significant G0/G1-phase arrest, and the percentage of cells in the G2/M phase decreased significantly compared with that of the DMSO-treated cells (Figure 1H); however, it did not affect the number of apoptotic cells (Figure S5). Compared with DMSO treatment, GM markedly suppressed the migration capability of SK-Hep-1 and MHCC97 cells as determined using the Transwell assay (Figure 1I and Figure S4B). GM decreased the invasiveness of HCC cells and inhibited the rate of artificial basement membrane penetration in SK-Hep-1 cells (Figure 1J). However, GM had no effect on the expression of vimentin, N-cadherin, E-cadherin, and β-catenin (Figure S6), which are markers for epithelial mesenchymal transition (EMT), thus excluding the possibility that GM suppresses HCC cell migration by inhibiting EMT.

    GM Suppresses HCC Formation In Vivo

    To examine the antitumor effect of GM in vivo, an animal experiment was performed by orthotopically implanting MHCC97-luciferase cells into severe combined immunodeficient (SCID) mice. After the injection of MHCC97-luciferase cells into the left outer lobe of the liver, mice were treated with phosphate-buffered saline (PBS), 20 mg of enoxacin/kg, 20 mg of sorafenib/kg, or 20 or 40 mg of GM/kg. Imaging and quantitative bioluminescence analysis of the tumor revealed a marked decrease in the luminescence area in all treatment groups compared with the control (Figure 2A,B). Additionally, 20 mg of GM/kg showed greater anti-HCC efficacy compared with enoxacin and reduced anti-HCC efficacy compared with sorafenib. However, 40 mg of GM/kg demonstrated efficacy comparable to that of sorafenib. Consistent with the results of the bioluminescence analysis, enoxacin, sorafenib, and GM markedly reduced tumor size (black arrow in Figure 2C). Beyond that, intrahepatic metastasis in control, enoxacin, and 20 mg of GM/kg groups was observed from a liver image (red arrow in Figure 2C); simultaneously, 40 mg of GM and sorafenib per kilogram treatment suppressed intrahepatic metastasis (Figure 2C). While the body weight of mice increased in both groups, there were no obvious changes between the body weight of mice that received drugs and that of control mice at the end of the experiment (Figure 2D). Hematoxylin and eosin (H&E) staining revealed that GM markedly attenuated the infiltration of inflammatory cells in the left outer lobe of the liver (Figure 2E). Furthermore, we examined the status of inflammation infiltration in the middle lobe of the liver and found less infiltration in the enoxacin, sorafenib, and GM (40 mg/kg) (Figure 2F). Collectively, these results showing that GM exerts a suppressive effect on tumor burden provide in vivo confirmation of the in vitro findings that GM inhibits HCC proliferation and migration.

    GM Modulates miRNA Expression and the Proteome in HCC Cells

    To examine the profile of miRNAs in response to GM, we analyzed global miRNA expression profiles using a comprehensive miRNA microarray platform following the treatment of SK-Hep-1 cells. Small RNA libraries of the control and GM-treated SK-Hep-1 cells were constructed as described in the legend of Figure S7. All control and GM treatments generated approximately 10 million clean tags, which were then searched against the miRBase database (release 21) to identify known human miRNAs (Figure S8A). Consequently, approximately 700 miRNAs were identified in each group (Figure S8B). On the basis of the expression in each sample, miRNA expression was calculated and normalized to transcripts per million. A total of 69 differentially expressed miRNAs (p < 0.05, >2-fold change) were identified between the two groups, including 36 upregulated and 33 downregulated miRNAs (Figure 3A and Table S1), suggesting that GM regulated only a subset of miRNAs. Overall, the differentially expressed miRNAs (57 of 69) have been demonstrated to participate in cancer development and prognosis (Table S1). Considered previous reports that miR-10b-5p,(33) miR-497-5p,(37) miR-146a-5p,(38) and miR-224-5p(35) affected the cancer cell proliferation and metastasis in liver cancer, all of them were chosen for quantitative analysis with quantitative real-time polymerase chain reaction (qRT-PCR). Consistent with miRNAomics, the qRT-PCR results showed that GM treatment enhanced the expression of miR-497-5p and miR-146a-5p in a concentration-dependent manner and decreased that of miR-10b-5p and miR-224-5p (Figure 3B). Functional enrichment analysis of these miRNA target genes revealed that the downstream regulation of GM involves nucleic acid-binding transcription factor activity, transmembrane transporter activity, DNA binding, transporter activity, and signal transducer activity (Figure S9). Kyoto Encyclopedia of Genes and Genomes (KEGG) pathway enrichment analysis of miRNA target genes identified significantly enriched signal transduction pathways, such as phosphatidyl inositide 3-kinases protein kinase B (PI3K-Akt), Ras, mitogen-activated protein kinase (MAPK), and chemokine signaling pathways (Figure 3C). GM inhibited the phosphorylation of IκB, p65, MEK, AKT, and ERK1/2 but without a significant effect on the phosphorylation of p38, STAT1, and STAT3 (Figure S10).
    Isobaric tags for relative and absolute quantification (iTRAQ) and liquid chromatography-tandem mass spectrometry (LC-MS/MS) were used to analyze protein expression profiles (Figure S11). Three separate iTRAQ data sets were acquired to analyze GM and DMSO treatments each. The Pearson’s correlation coefficient revealed the high repeatability of protein expression between the two groups (Table S2). Using this approach, 93 differentially expressed proteins were identified (p < 0.05, >1.3-fold change), which included 37 downregulated and 56 upregulated proteins (Figure 3D and Table S3). Four of them affect cell growth and migration inhibition, including kinesin family member 14 (KIF14),(39) targeting protein for Xklp2 (TPX2),(40) ubiquitin conjugating enzyme E2 S (UBE2S),(41) and cell division cycle 20 (CDC20).(42) A Western blot assay was used to verify the expression levels of those proteins, which were consistent with the proteomics results (Figure 3E). Functional enrichment analysis of 93 proteins revealed that the significance of the gene ontology (GO) biological process changed after GM treatment and was related to antigen processing and presentation as well as a mitotic cell cycle (Figure 3F). The interactions among these 93 proteins were analyzed by a direct interaction algorithm, which revealed a network of 35 protein interactions that were mainly focused on cell division and antigen processing and presentation. Among them, CDC20 connected other up- and downregulated proteins (Figure 3G), which was consistent with our observation that GM suppressed the proliferation of HCC (Figure 1G,H). KEGG pathway enrichment analysis revealed that ubiquitin-mediated proteolysis, p53 signaling, antigen processing and presentation, glutathione metabolism, and primary immunodeficiency were enriched in differentially expressed proteins (Figure S12). Of the differentially expressed proteins, four (KIF14, TPX2, CDC20, and UBE2S) were selected and examined in tumor specimens from mice and the level of expression of all four proteins was decreased by GM (Figure S13).
    To identify the relationship between differentiated miRNAs and proteins, we performed an integrated analysis of differentially expressed proteins and miRNAs from proteomes and miRNAomes. Integrative analyses revealed that 27 miRNAs were directly associated with 24 proteins (25.8% of the total proteins) (Figure S14). Most proteins and miRNAs in those integrative relationships were associated with the occurrence and development of cancer. Furthermore, some miRNAs targeted more than one protein, such as miR-143-3p, suggesting that the modulation of miRNA biogenesis may exhibit greater efficiency in post-transcriptional regulation networks (Figure S14).

    TRBP Modulates the Anticancer Effect of GM

    To assess how GM regulates miRNA maturation, we first examined the protein levels of RISC components, including Dicer, TRBP, and Ago2. We found that the expression of RISC components was not altered in GM-treated cells (Figure S15). Furthermore, the cellular thermal shift assay was used to detect interactions between the components and GM. The results showed that GM decreased the thermostability of TRBP (Figure 4A,B) rather than that of Dicer and Ago2 (Figure S16) following co-incubation with cell lysis at a series of concentrations and temperatures. To further examine the role of TRBP in GM-induced suppression of HCC cells, TRBP was transiently overexpressed or knocked in SK-Hep-1 cells (Figure S17). As shown in panels C and D of Figure 4, the level of cell proliferation was significantly decreased following the overexpression or knockdown of TRBP, indicating that TRBP plays a key role in tumorigenesis. Furthermore, overexpression of TRBP enhanced GM-induced suppression of SK-Hep-1 cells (Figure 4C). Meanwhile, the antiproliferative effect of GM was greatly attenuated when knocking down TRBP (Figure 4D), indicating GM had minimal side effects. Additionally, TRBP overexpression significantly enhanced GM-mediated suppression of cell migration (Figure 4E), whereas knockdown of TRBP attenuated the antimigration activity of GM in SK-Hep-1 cells (Figure 4F). These results suggested that TRBP mediates the anticancer effect of GM in HCC cells.

    GM Physically Interacts with TRBP

    The binding of GM to TRBP was first examined by chemical shift perturbation (CSP) and saturation-transfer difference (STD) nuclear magnetic resonance (NMR) experiments (Figure 5A–C). In the CSP spectra, the signals for C-5-OMe and C-8-OMe (3.788 and 3.877 ppm, respectively) in GM shifted to a high field and broadened with increasing concentrations of TRBP (Figure 5B). Conversely, the peak height for C-7-OMe (3.756 ppm) in GM decreased, although with a negligible shift, and the line width broadened as the concentration of TRBP increased (Figure 5C). The interaction between GM and TRBP was also supported by the STD spectra. Saturation pulses were applied to cover the range of approximately 8.29–8.79 ppm, in which the amide groups of TRBP are excited. In the STD spectra, signals of the same three methoxyl groups in GM in the presence of TRBP were observed (red row in Figure 5A–C), whereas no obvious STD signal was observed in the absence of TRBP (black row in Figure 5A–C). Second, the physical interaction between GM and TRBP protein was examined using surface plasmon resonance (SPR). Binding between GM and recombinant expressed full-length TRBP was measured using a CM5 sensor chip, which translated the binding signal to resonance units. As shown in Figure 5D, a KD of 8.06 μM was calculated when determining the affinity of GM for TRBP. In addition, stable interaction binding kinetics was observed, whereby the binding response unit decreased as the GM concentration decreased (Figure 5E). The effect of GM on the interaction between TRBP and Dicer was examined by immunoprecipitation. The addition of GM strengthened the interaction between TRBP and Dicer but had no effect on Ago2 (Figure 5F). These results confirm an interaction between GM and TRBP.

    Structure–Activity Relationship (SAR) of GM in the Modulation of miRNA Biogenesis

    GM is a natural product obtained from S. chinensis, but it is difficult to obtain or synthesize enough of this compound for drug development. Therefore, there needs to be structural simplification to pave the way for further structural optimization; therefore, we simplified the structure of GM by removing ring C, and active groups were introduced at C-8 of ring A and at C-4 and N of ring B in the new skeleton while retaining the main skeleton (Scheme 1). On the basis of our previous synthesis of compound 1 and intermediate 1-1,(43) 20 analogues of GM were synthesized to study the SAR of GM. As shown in Scheme 2, the acyl chloride was obtained by reflux of intermediate 1-1 in dichloro sulfoxide, and the amide compounds (2–6) was obtained by adding the corresponding primary amine. Started with compound 1, compound 7 was obtained by selective demethylation, which could be further chlorinated to form compound 8 or compound 9 with benzoyl chloride. In addition, compound 7 not only formed sulfonamide (10–14) with sulfonyl chloride but also corresponded to amides (15–17) with alkyl diamides protected by di-tert-butyl carbonate that could be removed in the presence of trifluoroacetic acid to obtain aminoamides (18–20).
    Their effects on miRNA expression were examined, and all GM analogues significantly affected miR-21 biogenesis (Figure 6A). Three analogues (3, 7, and 10) had a potency similar to that of GM, and compound 9 was more potent than GM. All of the analogues did not show any chemical features of pan assay interference compounds (PAINS) by ZINC filter. Compounds 3, 7, 9, and 10 decreased the intensity of the luciferase signal with IC50 values of 21.91, 15.61, 12.96, and 19.48 μM, respectively (Figure S18). Furthermore, the KD values of compounds 3, 7, 9, and 10 for TRBP by SPR were determined to be 17.97, 18.31, 6.79, and 24.08 μM, respectively (Figure S19). GM analogues were used to examine their antiproliferative activity in SK-Hep-1 cells and QSG 7701 cells. Compounds 3, 7, 9, and 10 had a similar or more potent inhibitory effect on cell proliferation than GM (Figure S20 and Table 1). The antiproliferative potency of compound 9 and GM at 20 μM was examined in MHCC97, HepG2, Huh7, and HeLa cells. As shown in Figure S21, compound 9 was more potent than GM in SK-Hep-1 and MHCC97 cells but with the same efficacy in HepG2, HeLa, and Huh7 cells. However, compounds exhibited low selectivity against tumor cells versus nontumor cells (Table 1).
    Table 1. IC50 Values of Compounds against SK-Hep-1 and QSG-7701 Cells
    compoundSK-Hep-1 (μM)QSG-7701 (μM)compoundSK-Hep-1 (μM)QSG-7701 (μM)
    enoxacin25.0372.351026.6761.35
    GM20.5652.981131.6867.89
    129.8968.541234.2569.32
    2>100>100.001328.6562.35
    323.5756.351446.9875.86
    438.4358.451539.6563.25
    531.5664.381689.65>100
    635.7856.891740.9159.47
    724.4567.2318>100.00>100.00
    822.6850.3219>100.00>100.00
    919.4348.352064.6574.15
    Upon comparing the biological activity of 1 with those of 2–6, we found that the introduction of an amide at C-8 of ring A caused a significant reduction in the antiproliferative activity. Introduction of a chain amide group at C-8 of ring A caused a potency lower than that of 1. Moreover, replacing the substituent at C-8 of ring A with a benzylcarbamyl resulted in a potency higher than that of 1, reaching a level comparable to that observed for GM. In addition, introduction of phenylcarbamyl could increase the activities (1 vs 4), and the substituent position on the phenyl ring had no effect on the activity (1 vs 5 and 6). By comparing the effect of ring B, we found that removing a methyl from a tertiary amine increased antiproliferative activity as demonstrated by 7 versus 1. The activity was further increased after chlorination at C-4 of ring B (7 vs 8). In addition, it was also favorable to improve the activity when the NH group of 7 was protected with benzoyl (7 vs 9). When benzoyl was replaced with similar sulfonic groups (10–14), the biological activity was reduced compared with that of 7. Amino side chains were also introduced at the NH group of 7, and deletion of the butyloxy carbonyl group resulted in decreased activity, as demonstrated by 15–17 compared with those of 18–20. However, the activities of 15–20 remained lower than those of 7 with regard to antiproliferation.
    On the basis of the SAR of these analogues, compound 7 was chosen to label the biotin probe to obtain 21 (Scheme 3). The effect of 21 on miR-21 biogenesis was similar to that of compound 7 and GM (Figure S22). The ability of the biotin-labeled compound to inhibit proliferation and metastasis was examined in SK-Hep-1 cells. Both 7 and 21 were found to effectively suppress the proliferation (Figure 6B), invasion (top panel in Figure 6C), and migration (bottom panel in Figure 6C) of hepatoma cells. To further investigate the interaction between 21 and TRBP, the compound was used to pull down TRBP. As shown in Figure 6D, 21 was found to interact with TRBP and this binding could be competitively inhibited by 7 or GM, with the latter resulting in the strongest inhibition (Figure 6D). Considering that enoxacin has been reported to target piwi-like protein 3 (PIWIL3) and topoisomerase 2β (TOP2β),(44,45) compound 21 was used to pull down PIWIL3 and TOP2β. Our results showed that 21 did not bind those proteins (Figure S23).

    Discussion and Conclusion

    ARTICLE SECTIONS
    Jump To
    TRBP phosphorylation is mediated by the MAPK pathway.(16) Interestingly, Gomisin A ameliorated metastatic melanoma by increasing the level of ERK activation. Supported by our observation that GM regulates the MAPK signaling pathway in miRNAome analysis, it is possible that GM may regulate the ERK/MAPK pathway and indirectly modulate TRBP activity for microRNA biogenesis; however, this requires further investigation. The function of TRBP can also be affected by its interacting proteins, including double-stranded RNA-specific adenosine deaminase (ADAR1),(46) PKR-associated protein X (PACT), and protein kinase R (PKR).(47) In addition, TRBP affects translation by binding to the structured 3′ untranslated region (UTR) of mRNAs,(48) and destabilization of metastasis suppressor transcripts could be affected by the binding of TRBP to mRNA hairpins.(49) Therefore, further research is needed to determine whether GM regulates the interaction between TRBP and other proteins, or a group of specific mRNAs, to jointly suppress HCC.
    Sorafenib is used widely in the treatment of advanced HCC; however, it is associated with adverse events and the development of acquired resistance.(50) Here, we found that GM could inhibit the growth of human liver cancer cells in orthotopically implanted mice with greater efficacy than enoxacin at the same dosage (20 mg/kg) and with an efficacy similar to that of sorafenib at 40 mg/kg. Enoxacin inhibits the growth of various cancers, including colorectal and breast cancers.(11,44) In this study, we found that enoxacin also exhibits anticancer effects in HCC. In addition, TRBP overexpression suppressed the proliferation and migration of HCC cells. This was supported by the observation that enoxacin suppressed HCC tumorigenesis in vivo, consistent with the report that enoxacin activated TRBP in colorectal cancer.(11) GM was found to suppress the proliferation of xenografted liver cancer cells in vivo, which was also consistent with the observation that GM inhibited hepatocarcinogenesis induced by 3′-methyl-4-dimethylamino-azobenzene in rats.(51) Our data for the SAR of GM indicated that dibenzocyclooctadiene lignans may be valuable for further development as novel TRBP modulators in the treatment of HCC. Consistent with proteomics analysis results, we found that GM also suppressed the expression of KIF, TPX2, UBE2S, and CDC20 in vivo. Downregulation of Dicer by hypoxia is an essential process in HCC progression.(52) In contrast, staphylococcal nuclease domain containing 1 confers significantly higher RISC activity in HCC by interacting with Ago2.(53) Here, we found that GM promoted the interaction between TRBP and Dicer but had no effect on the interaction between TRBP and Ago2, suggesting that GM regulates the function of Dicer to exert its anticancer effect in HCC. A limitation of targeted therapies is drug resistance, which may be obviated by the development of drugs that act on multiple targets.(54) Considering the efficacy of GM in the remodeling of a subset of miRNAs and tumor-related proteins, targeting TRBP by GM or its analogues may be a novel strategy for inhibiting HCC tumorigenesis and progression.
    We observed a significant alteration with only a small subset of miRNAs, including 36 that were upregulated and 33 that were downregulated. This is consistent with previous studies showing that the knockdown or mutation of TRBP resulted in a subset, rather than a global change, of differentially expressed miRNA.(47,55) S6K2-mediated regulation of TRBP affects miRNA expression with different effects in human primary lymphatic endothelial cells.(15) Furthermore, enoxacin was also observed to differently affect miRNAs by targeting TRBP in HEK293 cells, colorectal cancer cells, and prostate cancer cells.(11,56,57) Therefore, it is possible that the expression level and variety of pre-miRNAs, their secondary structures, and post-translational modification of the RISC element may contribute to the effect of TRBP modulated by small molecules on the expression of specific miRNAs expression. The pathways enriched by the 69 miRNAs included the Ras, tumor necrosis factor (TNF), PI3K-Akt, Janus kinase/signal transducer and activator of tran-ions (JAK/STAT), MAPK, etc., indicating that these are involved in the anticancer mechanisms of GM in HCC. This is consistent with the observation that these pathways contribute to HCC tumorigenesis.(58) Proteomics analysis revealed that proteins related to cell division were enriched among those downregulated by GM, which is supported by our observation that GM suppresses HCC cell proliferation and migration in vitro and in vivo. This is because most proteins were involved in the proliferation and metastasis in HCC or other cancers, especially the kinesin superfamily, including KIF4A, KIF14, and KIF23. Moreover, many proteins associated with antigen processing and presentation were also enriched, including human leukocyte antigen A (HLA-A), human leukocyte antigen C (HLA-C), transporter 1 (TAP1), and TAP-binding protein (TAPBP). These proteins participate in the lysis of target cells by cytotoxic T-lymphocytes following recognition of peptide and MHC class I molecule complexes on cell surfaces. Therefore, GM may enhance tumor immunity in HCC, and this warrants further investigation. Recently, 628 therapeutic targets with potential for anticancer drug development were identified by genome-scale CRISPR-Cas9 screens in 324 human cancer models,(59) in which 10 proteins were found to be regulated by GM in HCC cells, including TPX2, sperm-associated antigen 5 (SPAG5), solute carrier family 38 member 2 (SLC38A2), KIF14, F-box and WD repeat domain containing 11 (FBXW11), DNA methyltransferase 1 (DNMT1), carboxypeptidase D (CPD), UBE2S, cyclin-dependent kinase 2 (CDK2), and alanyl-TRNA synthetase 1 (AARS), further explaining the anticancer mechanism of GM and promoting the development of GM as a novel therapeutic candidate for cancer treatment.
    TRBP was initially found to bind the stem–loop transactivation response RNA region of long terminal repeats on both 5′- and 3′-ends to promote the translation of HIV-1.(60) GM, Gomisin G, and Gomisin J have been found to exhibit anti-HIV activity.(24,61,62) However, the underlying mechanism remains unknown. Here, we found that GM physically interacts with TRBP and modulates its function, suggesting that GM and its analogues exert their anti-HIV activity by targeting TRBP. This is consistent with previous reports that enoxacin, a validated TRBP agonist, also protected infected cells from HIV-1-mediated cytotoxicity.(63) In this study, we found that GM potently suppressed HCC cell proliferation, consistent with our observation that GM binds more potently to TRBP than enoxacin. We also found that GM promoted the binding of TRBP to Dicer, consistent with reports that TRBP modulates the activity of Dicer.(11,57) Enoxacin interacts with TRBP,(11) PIWIL3,(44) and topoisomerase 2β;(46) however, in our study, 21 could not pull down PIWIL3, indicating that 21 exhibited specificity greater than that of enoxacin. This is supported by the observation that GM did not further suppress the proliferation or migration of SK-Hep-1 cells with TRBP knockdown, suggesting that GM has minimal off-target effects.
    In summary, we found that GM and its analogues target TRBP to modulate miRNA biogenesis and alter the expression of a subset of miRNAs and cancer-related pathways, resulting in inhibition of HCC proliferation and metastasis. The findings of this study highlight a previously unrecognized role of TRBP in HCC. TRBP may be a potential novel therapeutic target in HCC, and dibenzocyclooctadiene lignans warrant further investigation as potential drug candidates for the treatment of patients with HCC.

    Experimental Section

    ARTICLE SECTIONS
    Jump To

    Chemical Information

    All reagents and solvents were obtained from commercial suppliers and used as received unless otherwise stated. DMSO, dimethylformamide (DMF), dichloromethane (DCM), 1,2-dichloroethane (DCE), and chloroform were distilled with molecular sieves (4 Å). All air sensitive reactions were carried out under an inert atmosphere (nitrogen gas). Purification was carried out by column chromatography on silica gel. Thin-layer chromatography (TLC) was carried out using commercially available aluminum sheets precoated with silica gel with a fluorescence indicator and visualized under ultraviolet light at 254 nm. Mass spectra were recorded on an LTQOrbitrapXL mass spectrometer (ThermoFisher). 1H and 13C NMR spectra were recorded on either 300 or 400 MHz instruments. 13C NMR data are reported with two decimals when recorded on an instrument with a cryoprobe. Chemical shift values are quoted in parts per million, and coupling constants (J) in hertz. 1H and 13C NMR spectra were referenced against residual solvent peaks. Samples for electrospray ionization (ESI) mass spectrometry were dissolved in MeOH, which was used as the carrier solvent. A high-performance liquid chromatography system (HPLC; Agilent 1260 Infinity II) assembled with a diode array detector was used to separate, identify, and quantify the compounds, and their purities were ≥95%. An AichromBond-AQ C18, 4.6 mm × 250 mm RP-C18 column was used as a stationary phase for chromatographic separation. Active compounds were checked for chemical features responsible for possible unreliable activity with patterns defined as PAINS by online filter ZINC (http://zinc15.docking.org/patterns/home/).

    General Procedure A. General Procedure for Amidation by 6-[4-(Dimethylamino)phenyl]-7-methoxybenzo[d][1,3]dioxole-5-carboxylic acid (1-1) and R1NH2

    Solid EDCI (1 equiv) was added in parts to the solution of 6-[4-(dimethylamino)phenyl]-7-methoxybenzo[d][1,3]dioxole-5-carboxylic acid (1-1) (63.00 mg, 0.2 mmol) in DMF (8 mL) at room temperature. The mixture was further stirred for 45 min, and then the R1NH2 (1 equiv) and DMAP (0.1 equiv) were added. After 8 h, the mixture was then poured into water (10 mL) and extracted with EtOAc (3 × 5 mL). The combined organics were washed with brine (3 × 5 mL), dried with MgSO4, and filtered, and the solvents were removed in vacuo. A simple column wash could give pure product.

    General Procedure B. General Procedure for Amidation by Methyl 7-Methoxy-6-[4-(methylamino)phenyl]benzo[d][1,3]dioxole-5-carboxylate (7) and Sulfochlorides

    Et3N (2.5 equiv) was added in parts to the solution of methyl 7-methoxy-6-[4-(methylamino)phenyl]benzo[d][1,3]dioxole-5-carboxylate (7) (63.00 mg, 0.2 mmol) in DCM (1 mL) at 0 °C. The mixture was further stirred for 10 min, and then R2SO2Cl (1.1 equiv) was added. Then the mixture was further stirred overnight at room temperature. After completion of the reaction, the mixture was neutralized with saturated aqueous NH4Cl, poured into water (10 mL), and extracted with DCM (3 × 5 mL). The combined organics were washed with brine (3 × 5 mL), dried with MgSO4, and filtered, and the solvents were removed in vacuo. A simple column wash could give pure product.

    General Procedure C. General Procedure for Amidation by Methyl 7-Methoxy-6-[4-(methylamino)phenyl]benzo[d][1,3]dioxole-5-carboxylate (7) and R3COOH

    Solid EDCI (1.5 equiv) was added in parts to the solution of R3COOH (1 equiv) in DMF (2 mL) at room temperature. The mixture was further stirred for 45 min, and then the 7-methoxy-6-[4-(methylamino)phenyl]benzo[d][1,3]dioxole-5-carboxylate (7) (63.00 mg, 0.2 mmol) and DMAP (0.1 equiv) were added. After 8 h, the mixture was then poured into water (10 mL) and extracted with EtOAc (3 × 5 mL). The combined organics were washed with brine (3 × 5 mL), dried with MgSO4, and filtered, and the solvents were removed in vacuo. A simple column wash could give pure product.

    General Procedure D. General Procedure for Removal of the Boc Protective Group

    CF3COOH (1.5 equiv) was added drop by drop to the solution of compounds 18–20 (0.1 mmol) in DCM (1 mL) at room temperature. The mixture was further stirred for 3 h, then neutralized with saturated aqueous NaHCO3, poured into water (10 mL), and extracted with DCM (3 × 5 mL). The combined organics were washed with brine (3 × 5 mL), dried with MgSO4, and filtered, and the solvents were removed in vacuo. A simple column wash could give pure product.

    Methyl 6-[4-(Dimethylamino)phenyl]-7-methoxybenzo[d][1,3]dioxole-5-carboxylate (1)

    Compound 1 was prepared according to previous research. Briefly, the methyl 7-hydroxybenzo[d][1,3]dioxole-5-carboxylate was prepared by the Williamson method in the presence of potassium carbonate from commercially available methyl 3,4,5-trihydroxybenzoate. The bromination reaction took place with the addition of dibromohydantoin to yield methyl 6-bromo-7-hydroxybenzo[d][1,3]dioxole-5-carboxylate, which was protected by methylation to provide methyl 6-bromo-7-methoxybenzo[d][1,3]dioxole-5-carboxylate.(64,65) Then the methyl 6-[4-(dimethylamino)phenyl]-7-methoxybenzo[d][1,3]dioxole-5-carboxylate (1) (60% yield) could be obtained by a Suzuki reaction.(43)1H NMR (400 MHz, CD3COCD3): δ 7.02–7.00 (2H, d, J = 8.8 Hz), 6.92 (1H, s), 6.73–6.71 (2H, d, J = 8.8 Hz), 6.10 (2H, s), 3.73 (3H, s), 3.48 (3H, s), 2.95 (6H, s). 13C NMR (100 MHz, CD3COCD3): δ 167.92, 149.70, 147.82, 141.35, 140.05, 130.55, 130.27, 126.51, 124.16, 111.50, 103.66, 102.06, 59.23, 51.04, 39.7. HRMS-ESI: m/z calcd for C18H20O5 [(M + H)+] 330.1336, found 330.1334.

    6-[4-(Dimethylamino)phenyl]-7-methoxybenzo[d][1,3]dioxole-5-carboxylic acid (1-1)

    According to previous research, compound 1 (650.0 mg, 2 mmol) was subjected to hydrolysis in the presence of sodium hydroxide to afford key intermediate 6-[4-(dimethylamino)phenyl]-7-methoxybenzo[d][1,3]dioxole-5-carboxylic acid 1-1 (540.0 mg, 85%) as a yellow solid.(42)1H NMR (300 MHz, DMSO-d6): δ 12.34 (1H, s), 7.00–6.97 (2H, d, J = 8.4 Hz), 6.94 (1H, s), 6.70–6.67 (2H, d, J = 8.5 Hz), 6.09 (2H, s), 3.68 (3H, s), 2.91 (6H, s). 13C NMR (75 MHz, DMSO-d6): δ 168.71, 149.17, 147.24, 140.76, 139.27, 130.17, 129.37, 127.29, 123.70, 111.44, 103.44, 101.81, 59.52, 39.44. HRMS-ESI: m/z calcd for C17H18NO5 [(M + H)+] 316.1179, found 387.1176.

    N-[2-(Diethylamino)ethyl]-6-[4-(dimethylamino)phenyl]-7-methoxybenzo[d][1,3]dioxole-5-carboxamide (2)

    Using general procedure A, compound 2 (60.00 mg) was obtained from compound 1-1 in 72% yield as a yellow solid. 1H NMR (300 MHz, CDCl3): δ 7.18–7.15 (2H, d, J = 8.7 Hz), 6.97 (1H, s), 6.74–6.71 (2H, d, J = 8.7 Hz), 6.00 (2H, s), 5.60 (1H, s), 3.76 (3H, s), 3.13–3.10 (2H, q, J = 5.1 Hz), 2.97 (6H, s), 2.35–2.28 (4H, q, J = 7.2 Hz), 2.18–2.14 (2H, t, J = 6.5 Hz), 0.88–0.83 (6H, t, J = 7.2 Hz). 13C NMR (75 MHz, CDCl3): δ 168.94, 149.91, 148.18, 141.02, 138.94, 131.22, 130.87, 127.46, 123.18, 112.26, 103.97, 101.64, 60.09, 51.12, 46.23, 40.52, 37.53, 11.35. HRMS-ESI: m/z calcd for C23H32N3O4 [(M + H)+] 414.2387, found 414.2387.

    N-Benzyl-6-[4-(dimethylamino)phenyl]-7-methoxybenzo[d][1,3]dioxole-5-carboxamide (3)

    Using general procedure A, compound 3 (69.00 mg) was obtained from compound 1-1 in 85% yield as a white solid. 1H NMR (300 MHz, CDCl3): δ 7.18–7.16 (3H, m), 7.12 (1H, s), 7.09–7.08 (1H, m), 6.86–6.85 (2H, m), 6.67–6.64 (2H, d, J = 8.7 Hz), 5.99 (2H, s), 5.43 (1H, s), 4.24–4.22 (2H, d, J = 5.1 Hz), 3.74 (3H, s), 3.97 (6H, s). 13C NMR (75 MHz, CDCl3): δ 168.43, 149.99, 148.29, 141.06, 139.13, 137.64, 130.79, 130.32, 128.42, 127.94, 127.69, 127.28, 122.83, 112.32, 104.25, 101.70, 60.08, 44.44, 40.45. HRMS-ESI: m/z calcd for C24H25N2O4 [(M + H)+] 405.1809, found 405.1809.

    6-[4-(Dimethylamino)phenyl]-7-methoxy-N-phenylbenzo[d][1,3]dioxole-5-carboxamide (4)

    Using general procedure A, compound 4 (58.00 mg) was obtained from compound 5 in 74% yield as a white solid. 1H NMR (300 MHz, CDCl3): δ 7.24–7.15 (5H, m), 7.03–6.99 (4H, m), 7.80–7.77 (2H, d, J = 8.7 Hz), 6.03 (2H, s), 3.79 (3H, s), 2.98 (6H, s). 13C NMR (75 MHz, CDCl3): δ 166.10, 150.46, 148.52, 141.02, 139.64, 137.99, 131.06, 130.03, 128.70, 127.89, 124.05, 122.55, 120.11, 112.90, 104.91, 101.85, 60.14, 40.61. HRMS-ESI: m/z calcd for C23H23N2O4 [(M + H)+] 391.1652, found 391.1650.

    6-[4-(Dimethylamino)phenyl]-7-methoxy-N-(3-methoxyphenyl)benzo[d][1,3]dioxole-5-carboxamide (5)

    Using general procedure A, compound 5 (67.00 mg) was obtained from compound 1-1 in 80% yield as a yellow solid. 1H NMR (300 MHz, CDCl3): δ 7.24–7.21 (2H, d, J = 8.7 Hz), 7.06–7.01 (2H, m), 6.81–6.78 (2H, d, J = 8.7 Hz), 6.68 (1H, s), 6.57–6.54 (2H, m), 6.04 (2H, s), 3.80 (3H, s), 3.71 (3H, s), 2.98 (6H, s). 13C NMR (75 MHz, CDCl3): δ 165.97, 159.94, 150.40, 148.57, 141.03, 139.70, 139.16, 131.12, 129.90, 129.37, 127.93, 122.50, 112.83, 112.36, 110.49, 105.23, 104.97, 101.88, 60.16, 55.19, 40.52. HRMS-ESI: m/z calcd for C24H25N2O5 [(M + H)+] 421.1758, found 421.1757.

    6-[4-(Dimethylamino)phenyl]-N-(3-iodophenyl)-7-methoxybenzo[d][1,3]dioxole-5-carboxamide (6)

    Using general procedure A, compound 6 (46.00 mg) was obtained from compound 5 in 45% yield as a yellow solid. 1H NMR (300 MHz, CDCl3): δ 8.14–8.11 (1H, d, J = 6.9 Hz), 7.65–7.63 (1H, d, J = 7.8 Hz), 7.29–7.24 (4H, m), 7.05 (1H, s), 6.78–6.73 (1H, t, J = 7.5 Hz), 6.71–6.68 (2H, d, J = 8.4 Hz), 6.04 (2H, s), 3.80 (3H, s), 2.91 (6H, s). 13C NMR (75 MHz, CDCl3): δ 167.39, 150.33, 148.33, 141.19, 139.65, 138.94, 131.31, 130.63, 129.02, 127.98, 125.79, 122.18, 122.00, 112.59, 104.21, 101.86, 89.85, 60.13, 40.58. HRMS-ESI: m/z calcd for C23H22IN2O4 [(M + H)+] 517.0619, found 517.0618.

    Methyl 7-Methoxy-6-[4-(methylamino)phenyl]benzo[d][1,3]dioxole-5-carboxylate (7)

    To a solution of methyl 6-[4-(dimethylamino)phenyl]-7-methoxybenzo[d][1,3]dioxole-5-carboxylate (1) (330.0 mg, 1 mmol) in DCE (6 mL) was added α-chloroethyl chloroformate (ACE-Cl) (0.65 mL, 6 mmol) in small portions at 0 °C with stirring. The mixture was further stirred for 15 min, then heated to 100 °C, and refluxed for 36 h. After the mixture had cooled, the solvents were evaporated in vacuo. The residue was dissolved in 3 mL of DCE; to the solution was then added 6 mL of EtOH, and the mixture was heated to 100 °C and refluxed overnight. After completion of the reaction, the mixture was allowed to cool to room temperature, then neutralized with 2 N NaOH, poured into water (150 mL), and extracted with DCM (3 × 50 mL). The combined organics were washed with brine (3 × 50 mL), dried with MgSO4, and filtered, and the solvents were removed in vacuo. The residue was purified by flash column chromatography (EtOAc/n-hexane = 1/10) to afford compound 7 (140.0 mg, 45%) as a yellow solid. 1H NMR (300 MHz, CDCl3): δ 6.98–6.95 (2H, d, J = 8.4 Hz), 6.95 (1H, s), 6.56–6.54 (2H, d, J = 8.7 Hz), 5.96 (2H, s), 3.69 (3H, s), 3.49 (3H, s), 2.79 (3H, s). 13C NMR (75 MHz, CDCl3): δ 168.36, 148.28, 147.68, 141.40, 140.13, 131.19, 130.32, 125.80, 125.02, 111.76, 104.39, 101.73, 59.99, 51.89, 30.68. HRMS-ESI: m/z calcd for C17H18NO5 [(M + H)+] 316.1179, found 316.1179.

    Methyl 6-[3-Chloro-4-(methylamino)phenyl]-7-methoxybenzo[d][1,3]dioxole-5-carboxylate (8)

    To a solution of methyl 7-methoxy-6-[4-(methylamino)phenyl]benzo[d][1,3]dioxole-5-carboxylate (7) (63.00 mg, 0.2 mmol) in DCM (1 mL) was added N-chlorosuccinimide (NCS) (41.00 mg, 0.3 mmol) under a N2 atmosphere at room temperature. After 1 h, the reaction was quenched by NaHCO3, and the mixture poured into water (10 mL) and extracted with DCM (3 × 5 mL). The combined organics were washed with brine (3 × 5 mL), dried with MgSO4, and filtered, and the solvents were removed in vacuo. The residue was purified by flash column chromatography (EtOAc/n-hexane = 1/10) to afford compound 8 (44.10 mg, 70%) as a yellow solid. 1H NMR (300 MHz, CDCl3): δ 7.13 (1H, s), 7.03–6.99 (2H, m), 6.66–6.63 (1H, d, J = 8.1 Hz), 6.02 (2H, s), 4.37 (1H, s), 3.79 (3H, s), 3.79 (3H, s), 2.92 (3H, s). 13C NMR (75 MHz, CDCl3): δ 168.08, 148.16, 144.06, 141.54, 140.22, 130.10, 130.00, 129.25, 125.87, 129.25, 118.48, 109.98, 104.60, 101.95, 60.12, 52.04, 30.50. HRMS-ESI: m/z calcd for C17H17ClNO5 [(M + H)+] 350.0790, found 350.0790.

    Methyl 7-Methoxy-6-[4-(N-methylbenzamido)phenyl]benzo[d][1,3]dioxole-5-carboxylate (9)

    Et3N (0.068 mL, 0.5 mmol) was added in parts to the solution of methyl 7-methoxy-6-[4-(methylamino)phenyl]benzo[d][1,3]dioxole-5-carboxylate (7) (63.00 mg, 0.2 mmol) in DCM (1 mL) at 0 °C. The mixture was further stirred for 10 min, and then benzoyl chloride (0.026 mL, 0.22 mmol) was added. Then the mixture was further stirred overnight at room temperature. After completion of the reaction, the mixture was neutralized with saturated aqueous NH4Cl, poured into water (10 mL), and extracted with DCM (3 × 5 mL). The combined organics were washed with brine (3 × 5 mL), dried with MgSO4, and filtered, and the solvents were removed in vacuo. The residue was purified by flash column chromatography (EtOAc/n-hexane = 1/10) to afford compound 9 (59.00 mg, 70%) as a yellow solid. 1H NMR (300 MHz, CDCl3): δ 7.29–7.27 (2H, d, J = 6.3 Hz), 7.26 (1H, s), 7.16–7.11 (3H, m), 6.98–6.97 (5H, m), 5.95 (2H, s), 3.6 (3H, s), 3.47 (3H, s), 3.35 (3H, s). 13C NMR (75 MHz, CDCl3): δ 170.76, 167.48, 148.47, 143.55, 141.01, 140.36, 135.20, 130.35, 129.92, 129.52, 128.87, 127.75, 126.18, 125.24, 104.77, 102.07, 59.98, 51.84, 38.43. HRMS-ESI: m/z calcd for C24H22NO6 [(M + H)+] 420.1442, found 420.1443.

    Methyl 7-Methoxy-6-[4-(N-methylphenylsulfonamido)phenyl]benzo[d][1,3]dioxole-5-carboxylate (10)

    Using general procedure B, compound 10 (69.00 mg) was obtained from compound 7 in 78% yield as a white solid. 1H NMR (300 MHz, CDCl3): δ 7.58–7.55 (3H, m), 7.48–7.46 (2H, d, J = 7.2 Hz), 7.11–7.10 (5H, m), 6.06 (2H, s), 3.78 (3H, s), 3.56 (3H, s), 3.22 (3H, s). 13C NMR (75 MHz, CDCl3): δ 148.58, 140.21, 136.06, 132.89, 130.10, 128.79, 128.04, 125.69, 125.45, 104.90, 102.13, 60.14, 51.95, 38.11. HRMS-ESI: m/z calcd for C23H22NO7S [(M + H)+] 456.1111, found 456.1110.

    Methyl-6-{4-[(4-fluoro-N-methylphenyl)sulfonamido]phenyl}-7-methoxybenzo[d][1,3]dioxole-5-carboxylate (11)

    Using general procedure B, compound 11 (63.00 mg) was obtained from compound 7 in 77% yield as a yellow solid. 1H NMR (300 MHz, CDCl3): δ 7.58–7.53 (2H, m), 7.16–7.10 (7H, m), 6.06 (2H, s), 3.79 (3H, s), 3.58 (3H, s), 3.22 (3H, s). 13C NMR (75 MHz, CDCl3): δ 167.32, 148.60, 141.11, 140.31, 139.99, 136.27, 132.37, 130.76, 130.64, 130.17, 125.60, 125.29, 116.17, 115.87, 104.89, 102.13, 60.09, 51.90, 38.03. HRMS-ESI: m/z calcd for C23H21FNO7S [(M + H)+] 474.1017, found 474.1017.

    Methyl 7-Methoxy-6-{4-[(N-methyl-4-nitrophenyl)sulfonamido]phenyl}benzo[d][1,3]dioxole-5-carboxylate (12)

    Using general procedure B, compound 12 (63.00 mg) was obtained from compound 7 in 63% yield as a yellow solid. 1H NMR (300 MHz, CDCl3): δ 8.31–8.28 (2H, d, J = 8.7 Hz), 7.71–6.68 (2H, d, J = 8.7 Hz), 7.13–7.09 (5H, m), 6.07 (2H, s), 3.81 (3H, s), 3.63 (3H, s), 3.27 (3H, s). 13C NMR (75 MHz, CDCl3): δ 166.97, 150.23, 148.68, 141.82, 141.09, 140.29, 139.27, 136.87, 130.41, 129.25, 125,47, 124.03, 104.96, 102.16, 60.10, 51.98, 38.16. HRMS-ESI: m/z calcd for C23H21N2O9S [(M + H)+] 501.0962, found 501.0960.

    Methyl 6-{4-[(4-Bromo-N-methylphenyl)sulfonamido]phenyl}-7-methoxybenzo[d][1,3]dioxole-5-carboxylate (13)

    Using general procedure B, compound 7 (93.00 mg) was obtained from compound 7 in 87% yield as a yellow solid. 1H NMR (300 MHz, CDCl3): δ 7.60–7.58 (2H, d, J = 8.7 Hz), 7.40–7.38 (1H, d, J = 8.4 Hz), 7.12–7.10 (5H, m), 6.07 (2H, s), 3.79 (3H, s), 3.58 (3H, s), 3.22 (3H, s). 13C NMR (75 MHz, CDCl3): δ 167.35, 148.63, 141.13, 140.32, 139.88, 136.36, 135.29, 132.09, 130.23, 129.56, 127.95, 125.61, 125.33, 104.92, 102.14, 60.13, 51.96, 38.08.     Methyl (S)-6-(4-{2-[(tert-Butoxycarbonyl)amino]-N-methylpropanamido}phenyl)-7-methoxybenzo[d][1,3]dioxole-5-carboxylate (17)

    Using general procedure C, compound 17 (71.00 mg) was obtained from compound 7 in 73% yield as a yellow oil. 1H NMR (300 MHz, CDCl3): δ 7.28 (4H, s), 7.12 (1H, s), 6.07 (2H, s), 5.43–5.41 (1H, d, J = 8.1 Hz), 4.44–4.40 (1H, t, J = 6.9 Hz), 3.82 (3H, s), 3.52 (3H, s), 3.33 (3H, s), 1.45 (3H, s), 1.42 (6H, s), 1.15–1.13 (3H, d, J = 6.6 Hz). 13C NMR (75 MHz, CDCl3): δ 173.51, 167.82, 155.09, 148.74, 141.41, 141.07, 140.23, 137.22, 131.25, 129.55, 126.65, 125.62, 104.94, 102.12, 60.10, 51.96, 47.11, 38.06, 28.48, 18.96.     Methyl 6-[4-(2-Amino-N-methylacetamido)phenyl]-7-methoxybenzo[d][1,3]dioxole-5-carboxylate (18)

    Using general procedure D, compound 18 (39.00 mg) was obtained from compound 15 in 83% yield as a white solid. 1H NMR (300 MHz, CDCl3): δ 7.26–7.24 (4H, m), 7.11 (1H, s), 6.06 (2H, s), 5.43 (1H, s), 3.78 (3H, s), 3.63 (2H, s), 3.51 (3H, s), 3.29 (3H, s). 13C NMR (75 MHz, CDCl3): δ 167.52, 166.21, 148.93, 141.18, 140.44, 139.26, 138.55, 131.82, 129.68, 126.07, 124.90, 105.04, 102.24, 59.99, 51.99, 41.07, 37.69.     Methyl 7-Methoxy-6-{4-[N-methyl-2-(methylamino)acetamido]phenyl}benzo[d][1,3]dioxole-5-carboxylate (19)

    Using general procedure D, compound 19 (32.00 mg) was obtained from compound 16 in 59% yield as a yellow solid. 1H NMR (300 MHz, CDCl3): δ 7.28–7.17 (4H, m), 7.13 (1H, s), 6.08 (2H, s), 3.82 (3H, s), 3.53 (3H, s), 3.35 (3H, s), 3.15 (2H, s), 2.36 (3H, s), 2.23 (1H, s). 13C NMR (75 MHz, CDCl3): δ 171.33, 167.49, 148.72, 141.51, 141.08, 140.27, 137.10, 131.11, 129.75, 126.42, 125.35, 104.92, 102.13, 60.09, 52.89, 51.88, 37.35, 36.41. HRMS-ESI: m/z calcd for C20H23N2O6 [(M + H)+] 387.1551, found 387.1551.

    Methyl (S)-6-[4-(2-Amino-N-methylpropanamido)phenyl]-7-methoxybenzo[d][1,3]dioxole-5-carboxylate (20)

    Using general procedure D, compound 20 (15.00 mg) was obtained from compound 17 in 49% yield as a yellow oil. 1H NMR (300 MHz, CDCl3): δ 7.28–7.19 (4H, m), 7.13 (1H, s), 6.08 (2H, s), 3.81 (3H, s), 3.58 (1H, s), 3.52 (3H, s), 3.33 (3H, s), 1.77 (2H, s), 1.16–1.14 (3H, d, J = 6.6 Hz). 13C NMR (75 MHz, CDCl3): δ 176.84, 167.53, 148.74, 142.00, 141.08, 140.27, 137.05, 131.13, 129.69, 126.56, 125.39, 104.94, 102.14, 60.10, 51.88, 47.39, 37.85, 21.71. HRMS-ESI: m/z calcd for C20H23N2O6 [(M + H)+] 387.1551, found 387.1551.

    Methyl 7-Methoxy-6-[4-(N-methyl-6-{5-[(3aS,4S,6aR)-2-oxohexahydro-1H-thieno[3,4-d]imidazol-4-yl]pentanamido}hexanamido)phenyl]benzo[d][1,3]dioxole-5-carboxylate (21)

    Solid EDCI (58.00 mg, 0.3 mmol) was added in parts to the solution of (+)-biotin-ε-aminocaproic acid (71 mg, 0.2 mmol) in DMF (2 mL) at room temperature. The mixture was further stirred for 45 min, and then the 7-methoxy-6-[4-(methylamino)phenyl]benzo[d][1,3]dioxole-5-carboxylate (7) (63.00 mg, 0.2 mmol) and DMAP (0.1 equiv) were added. After 8 h, the mixture was then poured into water (10 mL) and extracted with EtOAc (3 × 5 mL). The combined organics were washed with brine (3 × 5 mL), dried with MgSO4, and filtered, and the solvents were removed in vacuo. The residue was purified by flash column chromatography (H2O/CH3OH/EtOAc = 1/1/20) to afford compound 21 (97.00 mg, 70%) as a white solid. 1H NMR (400 MHz, CDCl3): δ 7.22–7.20 (2H, d, J = 7.6 Hz), 7.16–7.14 (2H, d, J = 8.0 Hz), 7.10 (1H, s), 6.06 (2H, s), 4.49 (1H, s), 4.28 (1H, s), 3.79 (3H, s), 3.51 (3H, s), 3.28 (3H, s), 3.16–3.11 (3H, m), 2.90–2.86 (1H, dd, J1 = 12.4 Hz, J2 = 4.4 Hz), 2.74–2.71 (1H, d, J = 12.8 Hz), 2.18–2.13 (4H, m), 1.69–1.57 (5H, m), 1.41 (4H, s). 13C NMR (100 MHz, CDCl3): δ 173.32, 173.29, 167.43, 167.43, 148.60, 142.70, 141.01, 140.22, 136.58, 130.89, 129.77, 126.43, 125.25, 104.80, 102.06, 61.76, 60.28, 60.02, 55.75, 51.79, 40.49, 39.10, 37.31, 36.05, 33.84, 29.03, 28.30, 28.11, 26.50, 25.83, 25.00. HRMS-ESI: m/z calcd for C33H42N4O8SNa (M + Na)+ 677.2616, found 677.2618.

    Cells and Reagents

    HeLa, SK-Hep-1, MHCC97, MHCC97-luciferase, HepG2, HCT116, MDA-MB-231, Huh7, and QSG 7701 cells were obtained from the Cell Resource Center, Shanghai Institutes for Biological Sciences, Chinese Academy of Sciences, and grown in Dulbecco’s modified Eagle’s medium (DMEM) high-glucose or RPMI 1640 medium (Hyclone) and supplemented with 10% fetal bovine serum (FBS, Gibco, Grand Island, NY) and penicillin/streptomycin (Hyclone). GM was isolated from Schisandra wilsonianaas previously reported.(66) Enoxacin was purchased from Tokyo Chemical Industry (Shanghai, China), and sorafinib from Solarbio (Beijing, China). Plasmid pGL4.26, plasmid pCI-neo, Geneticin (G418) coenzyme, luciferin, and Oligo (dT) 15 Primer were purchased from Promega (Madison, WI). Superscript II was purchased from Invitrogen (Carlsbad, CA). Matrigel was purchased from BD Biosciences. Alamar blue reagent, propidium iodide (PI), annexin V-FITC, RIPA lysis buffer, phenylmethanesulfonyl fluoride (PMSF), IgG (rabbit IgG), protein A/G agarose, and the Fast Silver Stain Kit were purchased from Beyotime biotechnology (Beijing, China). All primers were purchased from Sangong biotech (Shanghai, China). Antibodies specific for CDC20, CDK2, and UBE2SE were purchased from ABGENT (San Diego, CA). Antibodies specific for TRBP, Dicer, Ago2, E-cadherin, β-catenin, vimentin, N-cadherin, TOP2β, STAT1, P-STAT1, STAT3, P-STAT3, p38, P-p38, IκB, P-IκB, p65, P-p65, MEK, P-MEK, AKT, P-AKT, ERK1/2, and P-ERK1/2 were purchased from Proteintech (Wuhan, China). The KIF14 antibody was purchased from Signalway Antibody (Nanjing, China). The TPX2 antibody and HRP-linked secondary antibody were purchased from ZEN-BIOSCIENCE (Chengdu, China). SYBR Green Master Mix reagents and prestained protein markers were purchased from Transgen (Beijing, China). pCMV-TRBP and TRBP siRNA (5′-GGAGTATGGGACCAGAATA-3′) were purchased from Sino Biological (Beijing, China) and RiboBio (Guangzhou, China), respectively.

    Establishing Stably Transfected Cell Lines and Luciferase Reporter Assay

    A luciferase-coding fragment was obtained from pGL4.26 and inserted into pCI-neo between the NheI and XbaI restriction sites to establish pCIneo-luciferase. The miR-21-5p target sequence (TCAACATCAGTCTGATAAGCTA) was annealed and inserted into the pCI-neo-luciferase plasmid between the SalI and NotI restriction sites to establish pCIneo-luciferase-miR-21. Then, the pCIneo-luciferase-miR-21 plasmid was transfected into HeLa cells, and G418 was used to screen stable cell lines influenced by changes in the expression of endogenic miR-21-5p. For the luciferase reporter assay and high-throughput screening, cells were seeded in 96-well plates and treated with small-molecule compounds for approximately 24 h. Following treatment, cells were lysed for 15 min using 100 μL of cell lysis buffer. Then, 50 μL of lysate was pipetted into black 96-well plates with 50 μL of luciferin substrate containing 0.1 M coenzyme and 0.48 mM luciferin following the instructions of the Promega luciferase assay systems. Bioluminescence was measured using a microplate reader. The activity of the compounds was determined on the basis of the levels of relative luciferase expression.

    Proliferation and Colony-Forming Assays

    Cells were seeded in 96-well plates at 45% confluence, washed twice with PBS after 12–16 h, and then treated with compounds or DMSO (vehicle control). After 24 h, 10% (v/v) Alamar blue reagent was added to each well, and cells were incubated for 1 h. Fluorescence was measured using a Varioskan Flash Multimode Reader (Thermo, Shanghai, China) at 450 nm absorbance. The colony-forming assay was performed in a 12-well plate containing 1000 cells/well. Cells were then treated with different compounds or concentrations, and the culture medium was changed weekly. After being cultured for 14 days, colonies were stained with crystal violet (0.1%) for 0.5 h and imaged.

    qRT-PCR

    TRIzol was used to isolate total RNA from cells according to the manufacturer’s instructions. The quality of extracted RNA was assessed by measuring the absorbance at 260 nm relative to 280 nm after resuspension in 30 μL of RNase-free water. First-strand cDNA was then synthesized with reverse transcription using Superscript II and different specific primers listed in Table S4 for miRNA. Oligo (dT) 15 Primer was used for pri-miRNA and pre-miRNA. SYBR Green Master Mix reagents and primer (Table S5) mixtures were used for qRT-PCR. Small RNA RNU6 and GAPDH were used as endogenous controls to normalize miRNA, pri-miRNA, and pre-miRNA expression. The threshold cycle number (Ct) was used for quantitative analyses, and relative RNA expression was analyzed by the 2–ΔΔC(t) method.

    Flow Cytometry Analysis

    Following treatment with 0.1% DMSO (negative control) or 20 μM GM for 24 h, SK-Hep-1 cells were fixed with 70% (v/v) alcohol overnight at −20 °C. The cells were then washed with PBS and stained with 50 μg/mL propidium iodide for 30 min while being shielded from light. Approximately 20000 events were collected for flow cytometric analysis of the cell cycle distribution using a BD FACScan flow cytometer (DOTmed, Inc.). To analyze apoptosis, SK-Hep-1 cells were stained with annexin V-FITC and PI, followed by flow cytometry using a BD FACScan flow cytometer. All data files were analyzed using ModFit LT 5.0.

    Transwell Assays

    Transwell assays were performed according to the manufacturer’s instructions to evaluate the migration and invasiveness of cells. Briefly, SK-Hep-1 and MHCC97 cells in serum-free DMEM were seeded (5 × 106 cells/mL, 200 μL/well) in the Transwell plates (Corning, Corning, NY), and DMEM containing 10% fetal bovine serum was added to the bottom chamber. The cells were allowed to migrate under different treatments for approximately 12 h at 37 °C. After that, the upper surface of the Transwell cells was removed by cotton swabs, and migratory cells were fixed with ethyl alcohol (95%) and stained with crystal violet (0.1%). The number of migrating cells (three different fields per well) was counted using an inverted microscope. To evaluate invasion, a similar method was used as described for migration, except that the upper surface of the Transwells was preincubated with 12.5% (v/v) Matrigel before the cells were seeded. All images were obtained after 24 h using an IX51 microscope (Olympus, Tokyo, Japan).

    In Vivo Animal Studies

    SCID mice were obtained from Chengdu Dossy Experimentals Co., Ltd. (Chengdu, China), and fed using specific-pathogen-free equipment in a temperature-controlled sterile room at 25 °C. All animal experiments were approved by the Committee of Animal Ethics of Chengdu Institute of Biology, Chinese Academy of Sciences (CIBCAS-2018-01), and performed in strict accordance with the Guide for the Care and Use of Laboratory Animals of the Ministry of Health, China. Fifty male mice (5–6 weeks of age) were fed adaptively for 1 week following arrival. MHCC97-luciferase cells were harvested overnight with free serum and then digested with cold PBS. The cells (1 × 105) in a total volume of 0.1 mL were injected into the left external lobe liver of SCID mice. Ten days after the injection, the bioluminescent signal was observed to examine liver tumor formation and 30 SCID mice with similarly sized tumors were then randomly divided five groups: model, 20 mg of enoxacin/kg, 20 mg of sorafenib/kg, 20 mg of GM/kg, and 40 mg of GM/kg (six mice per group). Mice were intraperitoneally administered PBS, enoxacin, sorafenib, and GM once every 3 days at the required dose. Enoxacin, sorafenib, and GM were dissolved in PBS with 5% (v/v) DMSO. The first day of administration was recorded as day 1. After the mice had been sacrificed by cervical vertebral dislocation, their liver tissue was collected, fixed with 10% formalin for immunohistochemistry, and stained with H&E 30 days after the first administration.

    H&E and Immunohistochemical Staining

    The mouse tissues were rapidly fixed in 10% neutral buffered formalin and embedded in paraffin. The samples were cut into 4 μm serial sections and stained with H&E. For immunohistochemical staining, paraffin sections were dehydrated and then deparaffinized. After nonspecific sites of antigens had been blocked with 5% (v/v) BAS, slides were incubated with the primary antibody overnight at 4 °C and then with secondary antibodies for 2 h at 25 °C. Finally, the slides were visualized with a 3,3-diaminobenzidine solution (Solarbio) and counterstained with hematoxylin.

    MiRNAomics

    Following the treatment with or without GM for 24 h, TRIzol was used to extract total RNA, and a size range of 18–30 nucleotides was enriched by polyacrylamide gel electrophoresis (PAGE). The 5′ adapters were then added to the RNAs after enriching 36–44-nucleotide 3′ adapter RNAs. Then, the ligated products were reverse-transcribed by PCR amplification to enrich 140–160 bp products and generate a cDNA library and sequenced using Illumina HiSeqTM 2500 by Gene Denovo Biotechnology Co. (Guangzhou, China).
    Bioinformatics analysis was implemented on the basis of the cDNA library and sequence. Raw reads were further filtered and then aligned with small RNA in the GenBank database (release 209.0), Rfam database (11.0), and reference genome. To identify miRNAs, clean tags were searched against the miRBase database (release 21) to identify known human miRNAs. On the basis of their expression in each sample, miRNA levels were calculated and normalized to transcripts per million as follows: transcripts per million = actual miRNA counts/total counts of clean tags ×106.
    Differentially expressed miRNAs (≥2-fold change, P < 0.05) across groups were identified using the following formula:
    Target genes were predicted using the software RNAhybrid(v2.1.2)+svm_light(v6.01), Miranda(v3.3a), and TargetScan (version 7.0). GO enrichment and pathway enrichment analyses were performed using the GO database (http://www.geneontology.org/) and pathway-related database KEGG (https://www.genome.jp/kegg/pathway.html), respectively. The formula for calculating the P value was as follows:

    Proteomics

    Proteomics were analyzed quantitively by means of SILAC labeling. Briefly, SK-Hep-1 cells grown to 80% confluence were labeled with either “medium isotopic amino acids” (l-d4-lysine/l-13C6-arginine) or “heavy isotopic amino acids” (l-13C/15N2-lysine/l-13C615N4-arginine) using a SILAC Protein Quantitation Kit (Pierce, Thermo). To attain a labeling efficiency of >97%, cells were grown for at least six passages before being harvested. Subsequently, the cells were grown in SILAC medium to obtain the desired cell number.
    SILAC-labeled cells were treated with GM and DMSO for 24 h. Each sample was tattered using a high-intensity ultrasonic processor (Scientz, Ningbo, China) at 4 °C, and the supernatant was collected and used to determine the protein concentration with a BCA kit after centrifugation. Protein extracts derived from the “medium”- and “heavy”-labeled cell cultures were mixed in a 1/1 ratio on the basis of the concentration of the measured protein. The mixture was treated with 5 mM dithiothreitol for 30 min at 56 °C and alkylated with 11 mM iodoacetamide for 15 min at room temperature in the dark. Next, the concentration of urea in the mixture was diluted to a maximum of 2 M by adding 100 mM NH4HCO3. Finally, the mixture was digested with trypsin (1/50 protein mass ratio) overnight and then for 4 h with a lower concentration of trypsin.
    The trypsinized peptides were fractionated by high-pH reverse-phase HPLC using an Agilent 300Extend C18 column (5 μm particle size, 4.6 mm internal diameter, 250 mm length). The peptides were combined into 18 fractions, which were analyzed by MS/MS using Q ExactiveTM Plus (Thermo) coupled online to UPLC. A Maxquant search engine was used to process the MS/MS data. Significant differences were determined by analysis of variance with a >1.5-fold change in DMSO versus GM. The GO annotation of the proteome was derived from the UniProt-GOA database (http://www.ebi.ac.uk/GOA/). The KEGG database was used to annotate protein pathways and identify functional enrichment.

    Western Blotting

    Cells were incubated in RIPA lysis buffer with the addition of phenylmethanesulfonyl (PMSF) for 10 min at 4 °C, followed by centrifugation at 18000g for 10 min. Sodium dodecyl sulfate–PAGE (10%) was used to separate proteins following transfer to NC membranes (Merck, Darmstadt, Germany). Prestained protein markers were loaded in parallel. The membranes were incubated with BSA (PBS, 5% BSA) for 1 h at 25 °C and then incubated with primary antibodies at a 1/1000 dilution with Tris-buffered saline: Tween (TBST; TBS, 0.1% Tween 20, and 5% BSA) for approximately 14 h at 4 °C. Finally, after incubation with the secondary antibody at a dilution of 1/5000 with TBST for 1.5 h at 25 °C, the bands were visualized and analyzed using ImageQuant LAS 500 (GE Healthcare, Pittsburgh, PA).

    Cellular Thermal Shift Assay

    Sk-Hep-1 cells were lysed in PBS-containing PMSF by freezing and thawing in liquid nitrogen three times and then centrifuged (20000g) for 10 min at 4 °C. The supernatant was collected and treated with DMSO or 50 μM GM for 30 min at 37 °C. Then, 60 μL samples were treated at a series of temperatures for 3 min each. The supernatant of the cell lysate was also divided into 60 μL samples, which were subsequently treated with different concentrations for 30 min at 37 °C, and the incubated samples were heated to 55 °C for 3 min. Then, the heated samples were cooled at room temperature for 3 min and centrifuged (20000g) for 10 min at 4 °C. The supernatant was used for Western blotting to evaluate the interaction between GM and proteins.

    Overexpression and Knockdown of TRBP

    pcmv-TRBP and TRBP siRNA (5′-GGAGTATGGGACCAGAATA-3′) were mixed with Lipofectamine 3000 (Thermo) and then incubated with SK-Hep-1 cells (2.5 × 106 cells per transfection). After 24 h, protein expression was detected by Western blotting.

    NMR Assay

    TRBP-His6 was cloned in a pCold I vector, expressed in Escherichia coli Rosetta, and purified using a prepacked HisTrapTM column (GE Healthcare) on ÄKTA prime plus. Then, 9 μL of a 1 mM GM stock solution was added to 441 μL of a TRBP-His6 solution at each concentration, and the samples were mixed well. The final NMR samples comprised 20 μM GM with 0, 7.5, 15, 30, and 60 μM TRBP-His6, each in 50 mM sodium phosphate, 150 mM NaCl, 2 mM β-Me, 2% DMSO-d6, 10% D2O, and 0.2% (w/v) NaN3 at pH 7.6. With regard to the stability of the purified TRBP-His6 and the efficiency of saturation diffusion in the STD NMR experiments, the NMR spectra were recorded at 279 K using a Bruker Avance 800 MHz spectrometer equipped with a QCI-cryoprobe. CSP experiments were performed using the 1H RD pulse program, with a series of samples. In the 1H RD pulse program, a “perfect echo” CPMG module (τ–180−τ–90−τ–180−τ, where τ is the delay between pulses) was incorporated to suppress artifacts from homonuclear scalar couplings and protein signals, and two W5 sequences were used to suppress the water signal. The total CPMG time was set to 60 ms. The STD spectra were recorded using the NMR sample of 20 μM GM with and without 30 μM TRBP-His6. Because of the low water solubility and relatively low concentration of GM (20 μM) compared to that of the added protein (30 μM), a modified STD pulse program with the “perfect echo” CPMG and two W5 modules (instead of the spin-lock and the excitation sculpting pulses in the original Bruker pulse program STDDIFFESGP.3) were used to suppress protein and water signals. The off- and on-resonance saturation frequencies were 40000 and 2866.9 Hz, respectively, from the water frequency. Then, 20 ms Gauss 1.1000 pulses were applied for saturation, with a total saturation time of 4 s. The carrier frequency on H2O was set to 4.954 ppm, as the reference for chemical shifts.

    BIAcore Binding Assay

    The kinetics of binding of GM to TRBP were analyzed using SPR using a BIAcore 2000 instrument with a CM5 sensor chip (GE Healthcare). TRBP protein at a concentration of 4 μg/mL was immobilized via amine coupling on flow cells 1 and 2 of the CM5 sensor, which was activated by injecting a mixture of N-hydroxysuccinimide and 1-ethyl-3-[3-(dimethylamino)propyl]carbodiimide hydrochloride. Consequently, TRBP was captured at a density of ∼2000 RU. HBS-P [10 mM Hepes (pH 7.4), 0.15 M NaCl, and 0.005% surfactant] was used to equilibrate the sensor surface with 5% DMSO for at least 5 h. A GM concentration series was diluted in HBS-EP buffer [0.01 M Hepes (pH 7.4) containing 0.15 M NaCl, 3 mM EDTA, and 0.005% surfactant p20] with 5% DMSO and then with flow cell 1 at the maximum flow rate of 30 μL/min. As a control, flow cell 2 flowed into HBS-EP buffer. To regenerate the chip surface, a 2 min pulse of 1 M NaCl was injected to remove the bound GM and return the sensorgram to baseline. SPR data were analyzed to measure the association rate constant, dissociation rate constant, and KD of the compound using BIA evaluation version 3.2.

    Co-immunoprecipitation Assay

    SK-Hep-1 cells were pretreated with GM and DMSO for 24 h, and then cytoplasmic proteins were extracted and incubated with the TRBP antibody or IGg overnight at 4 °C. Then, samples were further incubated with protein A/G agarose beads for 2 h at 4 °C. The mixture was centrifuged for 5 min and washed five times. Finally, the immunoprecipitates were resuspended in PBS and detected by Western blotting.

    Pull Down Assay

    Biotin-labeled compounds (30 μM) were bound to 80 μL of streptavidin agarose beads (Sigma) in 200 μL of 1× TE buffer overnight at 4 °C. The beads were washed three times with 500 μL of 1× TE and centrifuged three times at 2000 rpm. Then, TRBP in 500 μL of binding buffer [20 mM Tris-HCl (pH 7.6), 10% glycerol, 150 mM KCl, 0.1% NP-40, 1 mM DTT, 50 ng μL–1 BSA, and protease inhibitors] was added, and samples were incubated for 2 h at 25 °C. After binding, the mixture was washed six times with binding buffer to remove redundant and nonspecific binding proteins. Following the final wash, beads were resuspended in 40 μL of cold PBS and 10 μL of 5× sodium dodecyl sulfate sample buffer for silver staining with the stain kit.

    Statistical Analysis

    All experiments were performed using at least three independent repeated experiments. The statistical significance of variations among experimental groups was evaluated using a Student’s t test and one-way analysis of variance, and data were presented as means ± standard errors of means. Pearson correlation coefficients were used to evaluate the relationships of differentially expressed genes. P values of <0.05 were considered statistically significant.

      Hepatocellular carcinoma
      Villanueva, Augusto
      New England Journal of Medicine (2019), 380 (15), 1450-1462CODEN: NEJMAG; ISSN:1533-4406. (Massachusetts Medical Society)
      A review summarizing the main genetic alterations in hepatocellular carcinoma, key epidemiol. features, and evidence-based approaches to its clin. management.
