        Chen, D. F.; Zhang, S. X.; Xie, L.; Xie, J. X.; Chen, K.; Kashiwada, Y.; Zhou, B. N.; Wang, P.; Cosentino, L. M.; Lee, K. H. Anti-AIDS agents--XXVI. Structure-activity correlations of Gomisin-G-related anti-HIV lignans from Kadsura interior and of related synthetic analogues. Bioorg. Med. Chem. 1997, 5, 1715– 1723,  DOI: 10.1016/S0968-0896(97)00118-1
        [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
        62
        Anti-AIDS agents-XXVI. Structure-activity correlations of gomisin-G-related anti-HIV lignans from Kadsura interior and of related synthetic analogs
        Chen, Dao-Feng; Zhang, Shun-Xiang; Xie, Lan; Xie, Jing-Xi; Chen, Ke; Kashiwada, Yoshiki; Zhou, Bing-Nan; Wang, Pei; Cosentino, L. Mark; Lee, Kuo-Hsiung
        Bioorganic & Medicinal Chemistry (1997), 5 (8), 1715-1723CODEN: BMECEP; ISSN:0968-0896. (Elsevier)
        Bioactivity-directed fractionation of an ethanolic ext. of the stems of Kadsura interior led to the isolation and identification of 12 known lignans. Seven of these compds. were active as anti-HIV agents. Gomisin-G exhibited the most potent anti-HIV activity with EC50 and therapeutic index (TI) values of 0.006 μg/mL and 300, resp. Schisantherin-D, kadsuranin, and schisandrin-C showed good activity with EC50 values of 0.5, 0.8, and 1.2 μg/mL, and TI values of 110, 56, and 33.3, resp. Ten related synthetic biphenyl compds., five variously substituted bismethylenedioxy, dimethoxy, and dimethoxycarbonyl isomers and five brominated derivs. also were evaluated for inhibitory activity against HIV-1 replication in acutely infected H9 cells. The total syntheses of two new isomers are reported for the first time. The anti-HIV data indicated that the relative position and types of substituents on the phenolic hydroxy groups of either the natural lignans or the synthetic biphenyl compds. rather than the nos. of bromine(s) on the arom. rings are of primary importance. In the cyclooctane ring of the natural lignans, the position and substitution of hydroxy groups are also important to enhanced anti-HIV activity.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADyaK2sXmsVGrs70%253D&md5=132467a2f62b457e709c311cc49e3897
      63. 63
        Nozaki-Renard, J.; Iino, T.; Sato, Y.; Marumoto, Y.; Ohta, G.; Furusawa, M. Fluoroquinolones protect the human lymphocyte CEM cell line from HIV-1-mediated cytotoxicity. Cell Struct. Funct. 1990, 15, 295– 299,  DOI: 10.1247/csf.15.295
        [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
        63
        Fluoroquinolones protect the human lymphocyte CEM cell line from HIV-1-mediated cytotoxicity
        Nozaki-Renard, Junko; Iino, Takashi; Sato, Yoshinari; Marumoto, Yasumasa; Ohta, Genkichi; Furusawa, Mitsuru
        Cell Structure and Function (1990), 15 (5), 295-9CODEN: CSFUDY; ISSN:0386-7196.
        Infection of the human lymphocyte CEM cell line with the HIV-1 (human immunodeficiency virus type-1, LAV-1 strain) results in cell death. A fluoroquinolone antibiotic, ofloxacin, protected the infected cells from HIV-1-mediated cytolysis. Other fluoroquinolones, e.g. ciprofloxacin, norfloxacin, and enoxacin, also protected the infected cells from HIV-1-mediated cytolysis. The d-isomer of ofloxacin (DR-3354) was about 50-fold less effective than the l-isomer (DR-3355). Almost none of the rescued cells had detectable HIV-antigens and they could be maintained for long periods in vitro without drugs.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADyaK3MXhvF2isrg%253D&md5=5acc04da45143d08e6fcbd9c947abdfa

        Venkanna, A.; Poornima, B.; Siva, B.; Babu, B. H.; Babu, K. S. Towards the total synthesis of Schisandrene: stereoselective synthesis of the dibenzocyclooctadiene lignan core. Synlett 2018, 29, 908– 911,  DOI: 10.1055/s-0036-1591539
        [Crossref], [CAS], Google Scholar
        64
        Towards the Total Synthesis of Schisandrene: Stereoselective Synthesis of the Dibenzocyclooctadiene Lignan Core
        Venkanna, Arramshetti; Poornima, Borra; Siva, Bandi; Babu, B. Hari; Babu, K. Suresh
        Synlett (2018), 29 (7), 908-911CODEN: SYNLES; ISSN:0936-5214. (Georg Thieme Verlag)
        A stereoselective synthesis of the dibenzocyclooctadiene lignan core, I, of the natural product schisandrene (II) is described. Starting from readily available gallic acid, the synthetic strategy involves Suzuki-Miyaura cross-coupling, Stille reaction, and ring-closing metathesis (RCM) in the reaction sequence. The required asym. center at C-7' was established by an asym. redn. of a keto compd. using the Corey-Bakshi-Shibata (CBS) catalyst. In our approach, the eight-membered ring was achieved by RCM for the first time.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC1cXivFGrs7k%253D&md5=5d43e9211c044c53fb752dce4c5bd969
      65. 65
        Alam, A.; Takaguchi, Y.; Ito, H.; Yoshida, T.; Tsuboi, S. Multi-functionalization of gallic acid towards improved synthesis of α- and β-DDB. Tetrahedron 2005, 61, 1909– 1918,  DOI: 10.1016/j.tet.2004.11.083
        [Crossref], [CAS], Google Scholar
        65
        Multi-functionalization of gallic acid towards improved synthesis of α- and β-DDB
        Alam, Ashraful; Takaguchi, Yutaka; Ito, Hideyuki; Yoshida, Takashi; Tsuboi, Sadao
        Tetrahedron (2005), 61 (7), 1909-1918CODEN: TETRAB; ISSN:0040-4020. (Elsevier B.V.)
        The synthesis of mono-, di- and trisubstituted gallic acids and their ester with similar or different groups including different acetal and ketals is described. Regioselective bromination on two ortho-positions of Me gallate, which is very crucial for many org. syntheses, was achieved in high yield and purity. The α- (I) and β-DDB (II) were synthesized in high overall yield and purity from the regioselective bromo-derivs.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BD2MXoslGquw%253D%253D&md5=39d96d563db8b5c6cbce0ea22619c7ec
      66. 66
        Yang, G. Y.; Li, Y. K.; Wang, R. R.; Li, X. N.; Xiao, W. L.; Yang, L. M.; Pu, J. X.; Zheng, Y. T.; Sun, H. D. Dibenzocyclooctadiene lignans from Schisandra wilsoniana and their anti-HIV-1 activities. J. Nat. Prod. 2010, 73, 915– 919,  DOI: 10.1021/np100067w
        [ACS Full Text ], [CAS], Google Scholar
        66
        Dibenzocyclooctadiene Lignans from Schisandra wilsoniana and Their Anti-HIV-1 Activities
        Yang, Guang-Yu; Li, Yin-Ke; Wang, Rui-Rui; Li, Xiao-Nian; Xiao, Wei-Lie; Yang, Liu-Meng; Pu, Jian-Xin; Zheng, Yong-Tang; Sun, Han-Dong
        Journal of Natural Products (2010), 73 (5), 915-919CODEN: JNPRDF; ISSN:0163-3864. (American Chemical Society-American Society of Pharmacognosy)
        Twelve new dibenzocyclooctadiene lignans, marlignans A-L (1-12), together with 16 known compds., were isolated from the leaves and stems of Schisandra wilsoniana. The structures of 1-12 were elucidated by spectroscopic methods including 1D- and 2D-NMR techniques. Compds. 1-12 were evaluated for their anti-HIV activities, of which compds. 3, 6, 8, and 12 showed modest activities with therapeutic index values of 13.2, 15.6, 17.6, and 16.4, resp.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC3cXlvFKqtrY%253D&md5=f35c4b77e0a3ae4e9fa2f98aa5429a38

    • Supporting Information

      Supporting Information

      ARTICLE SECTIONS
      Jump To

      The Supporting Information is available free of charge at https://pubs.acs.org/doi/10.1021/acs.jmedchem.1c00018.

      • Additional figures illustrating the screening (Figure S1), the activities of GM (Figures S2–S5), miRNAomics and proteomics analysis (Figures S7–S14), the effect of GM on the expression of RISC elements (Figure S15), evidence that GM did not target Dicer or AGO2 (Figure S16), TRBP expression after transfection (Figure S17), activities of compounds 3, 7, 9, and 10 in HeLa-miR-21-luciferase cells (Figure S18), the KD values of compounds 3, 7, 9, and 10 (Figure S19), the activity of GM analogues against SK-Hep-1 cells (Figure S20), a comparison of the activity of GM and compound 9 (Figure S21), and the effect of compound 21 in HeLa-miR-21-luciferase cells (Figure S22), evidence that compound 21 did not target PIWIL3 or TPO2β, miRNAomics and proteomics data (Tables S1–S3), sequences of primers (Tables S4 and S5), NMR spectra, and HPLC data of (−)-Gomisin M1 and 7 (PDF)

      • Molecular formula strings of GM and 1–21 (CSV)
